intro: Gilia gracilis var. elatior, commonly known as the tall gilia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the family Polemoniaceae and is characterized by its slender, branched stems and clusters of small, blue to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in open, sunny habitats such as meadows and rocky slopes. Its leaves are narrow and lance-shaped, and it produces seeds in slender, cylindrical pods. It is often cultivated for its ornamental value and is adapted to thrive in well-drained soils.
